summary: On March 8, 2019, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas entered a final judgment against a Texas mother who was charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Houston, Texas, from June 2013 to June 2014, Mother was chronically homeless and was using illegal drugs. The complaint alleges that the Department of Family and Protective Services (DFS) provided her with a service plan that required her to: obtain employment, pay child support, attend therapy, find stable housing, and submit to weekly drug tests.  The complaint further alleges that Mother did not comply with the DFS' recommendation to terminate her parental rights.  In a parallel action, the Texas Attorney General's Office today announced that it filed an emergency action against Mother, charging her with violations of Section 5 of the Exchange Act.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the complaint, Mother consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins her from violating the above-mentioned provisions of the federal securities laws, orders her to pay a civil penalty of $10,000, and requires her to surrender her passport. The SEC's investigation, which is continuing, has been conducted by John Rymas of the Fort Worth Regional Office. The litigation will be led by Mr. Mascianica. The case is being supervised by Chedly C. Dumornay, Chief of the Division of Criminal Justice. The court will determine the amount of disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and civil penalties to be determined by the court upon motion by the SEC.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-5221. The Commission's Office of Advocacy and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors toÂ check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.Â The SEC encourages investors to check the backgrounds of people selling investments by using theÂ SECÂ institutions.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals.  Investors can also use the Investor Alert feature to quickly and easily identify whether there are any red flags of potential conflicts of interest. Â In a related case, the SEC filed a civil injunctive action on May 5, 2015, against Mother alleging that she was under the influence of illegal drugs and that she failed to comply with a DFS order requiring her to submit to a drug test.
